txt.en: Accompany Authi as he presents his case before King Thorin
Listen to Khîl's response before the king
Talk to King Thorin
Listen to the judgement of King Thorin
Talk to Authi
'I wish to go among my people, Hrostyr. Should they not more often hear my voice?'
'I have spent some time in thought these past few days.'
'Many are the dangers arrayed before our people.'
'It is my burden to choose for them which of these threats to oppose.'
'Come then, Authi! What is your complaint?'
'What false tales are these?'
King Thorin has chosen to hear Authi Gem-cutter's grievance, but he will not do so at his throne.
'Some dwarves say this name signifies he will do great things.'
'Is this true, Khîl?'
'Others say it is just a name.'
'Remember you speak to your king, Khîl!'
'But I say he will grow into his name.'
'That will be enough, Hrostyr.'
King Thorin has chosen to go among his people for the hearing of Authi's complaint.
'I say he will be Durin the Deathless come again!'
'This is highly irregular. Why does the king choose not to hear this grievance at his throne? Would he not be more comfortable at his high seat?'
King Thorin has chosen to go among his people for the hearing of Authi's complaint.
'My father Bránit kept a home in Járnfast.'
Authi Gem-cutter has asked for your help with bringing his grievance against Khîl Tale-spinner before the king.
King Thorin has chosen to go among his people for the hearing of Authi's complaint.
'I have not been there for many years.'
DNT - Blah!

'Khîl seeks to flatter me, but I am too wise a king to fall prey to such a tactic. I named my son Durin for my own reasons, and I do not feel the need to share them with Longbeards or with Zhélruka. He stays now in Járnfast with my brother Náin, Lord of the Iron Hills, and he will be king after me. If he is to be anything else is certainly beyond the sight of this Zhélruka.'

King Thorin strokes his beard, and you might detect a slight upturn among his whiskers. Does he smile in spite of Khîl's flattery or because of it?

'Durin the Deathless come again? Hmm. Imagine that!'
Talk to Hrostyr, King Thorin's personal guard
Authi has heard the king's judgement and now wishes to speak with you.
'The king ruled in my favour. Why then do I feel as if he also ruled against me? Did I win or did I lose?'
'I suppose we should be going, [placeholder]. Let us return to my home and perhaps we can make sense of this.'
'Authi Gem-cutter, you will accompany Khîl to Járnfast. Then you may return.'
'I cannot oversee every little feud between dwarves!'
King Thorin has chosen to go among his people for the hearing of Authi's complaint.
'[placeholder], I ask you to accompany Authi and Khîl on this errand.'
'Speak to my brother Náin at the Ironfort, and bring my son Durin back home.'
'It is time he learned the ways of the king.'
'That is all.'
'Not with enough, I warrant.'
'My king, this is most irregular.'
'Yes, my king.'
'Do you deny the truth of these claims, Zhélruka?'
'[placeholder], may I have a word?'
'I have arrived at a judgement.'
'Go ahead.'
'What do you mean?'
'That is enough, Zhélruka.'
'This is my judgement.'
'Khîl, you have stayed in Erebor for long enough. You must depart.'
'From what land do you hail?'
'Járnfast, you say? How fortunate. It guides my further commands.'
'I don't know if his mother's beard will go grey.'
'King Thorin, I am no Longbeard. I am of the Zhélruka.'
'But I speak to you with respect.'
'Each of my stories is built around truth, King Thorin.'
'King Thorin, may I say one thing first?'
'It is a point of pride for me that so many dwarves listen to my stories.'
''This is true!' they say of some. 'This is untrue!' they say of others.'
'I know you experience this too.'
'You named your son 'Durin.' It is a name of great import.'
'My king, it has come to my attention that Khîl has spread false tales about my family.'
'[placeholder] heard one such tale from a customer of ours, and later from Khîl himself!'
'Khîl claims my family's craft-skill has declined!'
'He claims we plan to leave the Mountain in disgrace!'
'Such lies will make my dear mother's beard go grey!'
Instance: Grievances
'An outrage! You scoundrel!'
'But, my king...'
'I understand, my king.'
